Il Paradiso del Cibo

Eating at Il Paradiso is similar to eating in someone's front room. The tables are crammed together and there is a large television on the wall playing Italian football and music channels (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Justyn Hardcastle)

Pub

Described by my housemate who hails from Huddersfield as a "pub pub" (apparently this means it's a real pub) <strong>The Phoenix</strong> is another hugely enjoyable York pub (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Peter Iveson)

Best of York No.2: El Piano

This recipe is for Spanish patties, or <em>Tinas</em>; a great favourite at EL PIANO, in York and in Andalucia

Band of the Week: Yello

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Black Swan Competition

Darren Aronofsky's <em>Black Swan</em>, released on the 21st January, is set to be one of this year's hottest releases. Starring Natalie Portman as a mentally fragile ballerina, who credited with the lead role in her company's production of Swan Lake, finds herself on a dark, sexual and exhilarating downward spiral

Golden Tickets

By James Bithell

Our man on the ground <em>Tom Killingbeck </em>cherry-picks the most appealing acts blazing a trail Yorkwards this term.

The Next Three Days

Some movie stars do their best acting when they escape from the blockbusters they're normally drawn to

Band of the Week: Death

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

The King's Speech

"Contains strong language in a speech therapy context." A warning that was added after the makers of <em>The King's Speech</em> successfully lobbied to have the film's rating taken down from a 15 to a 12A, it must be one of the funniest caveats ever attached to a movie by the British Board of Film Classification

Gauguin: Maker of Myth

The Tate Modern's current exhibition <em>Gauguin: Maker of Myth</em> is the first major exhibition showcasing his work in over 50 years. The block-buster show will undoubtedly make it one of the most viewed exhibitions of 2010 (Thumbnail credit Gauguin 'Nevermore O Tahiti', 1897 Image Credit: Tate Modern)

In Pictures: Swan Lake's Prima Ballerinas

With the upcoming release of Darren Aronofsky's much-acclaimed Black Swan, we take a look at the ballerinas who have been the leading ladies of Tchaikovsky's timeless ballet, Swan Lake.

Band of the Week: Orchestra Baobab

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Amer

Out of the depths of the French underground comes this bizarre and visceral meditation on sexual desire.

Love and Other Drugs

A redefinition of the rom-com? The flag-bearer of a new dynasty of film, nay, a new genre? No. But is it even trying to do such things? Yes. So let's analyse the facts.

The Way Back

Poor Peter Weir - after a string of critical successes, there's now a level of expectation applied to his films that, in comparison to other directors, is extraordinarily high

Of Gods and Men

"Men never do evil so freely and cheerfully as when they do it from religious conviction", reads Luc, the doctor of the isolated monastic village in which <em>Of Gods and Men</em> is set. A statement which the film will in many ways prove correct.

Lest We Forget

By James Bithell

As the year comes to a close, <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> reflects on the heroes of the musical world lost in the last twelve months.

Band of the Week: The Raveonettes

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

One million books

The gift of literacy is quite unlike any other - something that is sadly not as widespread as one would hope, nor is it always made the most of by those who possess it. The night of 5 March 2011 will be a date which could not only help change that, but which also marks the beginning of what could be a great event for many years to come.

Tron: Legacy

As a Christmas blockbuster, <em>Tron: Legacy</em> comes as a bit of a surprise. The original, after all, had a somewhat limited appeal, and one that's hard to transpose to 2010

Somewhere

It was in 2003 that Francis Ford Coppola's daughter Sofia emerged as a major new director with her second film, <em>Lost in Translation</em>

Lost Kubrick Footage Discovered

Christmas has come early this year for Kubrick fans, as, in an unlikely turn of events an extra seventeen minutes of footage cut from <em>2001: A Space Odyssey</em> has been discovered

2011: A Musical Odyssey

By James Bithell

Our very own Nostradamus <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> potentially inaccurately prophecises the freshest sounds of 2011.

Band of the Week: The KLF

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Grand Opera House York presents: Cinderella

This year saw Stuart Wade's second directing role at the York Royal Opera House, in the Christmas production of Cinderella.

The Movements: Impressionism

Light; water; spontaneity; transience; vibrancy. Before the 19th century art movement Impressionism, the full potential of these concepts remained somewhat untapped, and certainly laced into tight forms.

Leighton Meester named face of Missoni

Gossip Girl actress consolidates her position as style icon

Indie shop search App

Apple have recently launched a new App that acts as a solved treasure map for fashion followers, locating the destination of small boutiques and independent shops that would otherwise be overshadowed and hidden by large retail and departmental stores. Sarah Wolfe investigates.

Trainspotting 2 - A Disaster in the Making

'It will happen' confirmed Danny Boyle last week. Speculation has been circulating for some time upon the director's plans for a <em>Trainspotting 2</em>. Of course, this sequel already exists, in the form of Irvine Welsh's follow up novel <em>Porno</em>. Apparently it is begging to be made into a screenplay.

Catfish

<em>Catfish</em> is a movie which, released off the back of <em>The Social Network</em>, shows us a side of the social networking phenomenon 'Facebook' that we don't often tend to think about.
